unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Two-Sided
question_text:
Suppose a two-sample $T$-test gives appropriate evidence of a significant difference between the two samples at the $10\%$ level. Suppose a one-sided $T$-test was performed.
What is the greatest alpha level that would be considered statistically significant for this data?
solution:
If the test gives evidence at the $10\%$ level, this means the $p$-value must be less than $10\%$.

Since the problem states evidence of a difference was found, the test is a two sided test. In a two-sided test, the $p$-value is doubled, so when going to a one-sided test, the $p$-value will be half of what it originally was.

Therefore, we know the $p$-value must be less than $5\%$, giving significant evidence at the $5\%$ level. The highest the p-value could be is $5\%$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'B'.

Generally, two-sided tests are used if one simply wants to test if something is different from the status quo, while one-sided tests are used to determine if a specific increase or decrease has happened. For example, suppose a new additive is used in a certain laundry detergent.

One could perform a one-sided test to determine if this new additive results in increased whiteness of the clothing after washing or one could perform a two-sided test to determine if the whiteness of clothing is simply different when washed with detergent with this new additive.
